contentrichtext.text: {{Taxobox | name = Oriole Warbler | image = Flickr - Rainbirder - Oriole Warbler (Hypergerus atriceps) (1).jpg | status = LC | status_system = IUCN3.1 | status_ref = <ref>{{IUCN|id=106007422 |title=''Hypergerus atriceps'' | assessors=[[BirdLife International]] |version=2012.1 |year=2012 |accessdate=16 July 2012}}</ref> | regnum = [[Animal]]ia | phylum = [[Chordate|Chordata]] | classis = [[bird|Aves]] | ordo = [[Passeriformes]] | familia = [[Cisticolidae]] | genus = ''''' Hypergerus ''''' | genus_authority = [[Ludwig Reichenbach|L. Reichenbach]], 1850 | species = '''''H. atriceps''''' | binomial = ''Hypergerus atriceps'' | binomial_authority = ([[Rene Primevere Lesson|Lesson]], 1831) }} The '''Oriole Warbler''' (''Hypergerus atriceps'') is a small [[Cisticolidae|warbler]], the [[monotypic|only member]] of the [[genus]] ''Hypergerus''. This [[bird]] is a resident breeder in west [[Africa]] from southern [[Senegal]] to [[Cameroon]] and north [[Zaire]]. This [[skulking]] [[passerine]] is typically found in dense thickets usually near water. Oriole Warbler builds a large untidy [[bird nest|nest]] suspended from [[Arecaceae|palm]] leaves. These 20 cm long warblers have a long tail, strong legs and a long black [[beak|bill]]. Adults are light olive above, yellow below and have a black hood. The species' name refers to their resemblance to the unrelated but similarly black and yellow [[Oriolidae|orioles]]. The sexes are similar, but juveniles are duller. Like most warblers, the Oriole Warbler is [[insectivorous]]. The [[bird song|song]] is a loud whistled [[duetting|duetted]] ''toooo-ooo-eee-oooo, oooo-ooo-eee-oooo''. The male always leads the duet<ref>Slater, P.J.B.; Gil, Diego; Barlow, Clive R. and Graves, J.A.; ”Male-led duets in the Moho, ''Hypergerus atriceps'', and Yellow-crowned Gonolek, ''Laniarius barbarus''”; in ''Ostrich: Journal of African Ornithology'' Volume 73, Issue 1-2, 2002 pp. 49-51</ref> and the female answers, though this is done in a manner that is temperarily rather loose.<ref>Brumm, Henrik and Slater, Peter; “Animal Communication: Timing Counts” in ''[[Current Biology]]'' Volume 17, Issue 13, 3 July 2007, pp. R521–R523</ref> ==References== {{Reflist}}<!-- FieldianaZool51:91. --> * ''Birds of The Gambia'' by Barlow, Wacher and Disley, ISBN 1-873403-32-1 *Ryan, Peter (2006). Family Cisticolidae (Cisticolas and allies). pp. 378–492 in del Hoyo J., Elliott A. & Christie D.A. (2006) ''[[Handbook of the Birds of the World]]''. Volume 11. Old World Flycatchers to Old World Warblers'' Lynx Edicions, Barcelona ISBN 978-84-96553-06-4 * Nguembock B.; Fjeldsa J.; Tillier A.; Pasquet E. (2007): A phylogeny for the Cisticolidae (Aves: Passeriformes) based on nuclear and mitochondrial DNA sequence data, and a re-interpretation of a unique nest-building specialization. ''Molecular Phylogenetics and Evolution'' '''42''': 272-286.
